Posts.Content: Luckydog42 wrote: I am about to start chemo and will take Taxol/Herceptin each week for twelve weeks and then continue monthly with Herceptin. Has anyone been through this same combo of drugs, and did you lose all your hair? My doctor said most women do not lose their hair, but the side effects of Taxol state that it is common to lose hair. I am not going to run out and shave my head, but I would like a realistic idea of what will happen with my hair. Dx 10/1/2014, IDC, 0/1 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2+ Dx 10/1/2014, DCIS Surgery 11/17/2014 Lymph node removal: Right, Sentinel; Mastectomy: Right Targeted Therapy 12/19/2014 Herceptin (trastuzumab) Chemotherapy 12/19/2014 Taxol (paclitaxel) Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Taxol and Herceptin - hair loss Luckydog42 TTfan

Posts.Content: Nov 19, 2014 02:01PM Luckydog42 wrote: I updating just in case a anyone else has this question. It was quicker and easier than a biopsy. I was out in a chair and wheeled up to a mammography machine. Once they had me in the right position, I had the usual two shots to numb. Then they stick a small needle , take a picture with the mammogram machine, then if it is in the right spot, they release the seed. It was quick and easy. Afterwards, I was given a small bandaid. It looks like I got a shot; just a small dot on my breast. I took the bandaid off that day. If you had a biopsy, the seed placement will seem like a wall in the park. I feel this is more humane than having the wires placed. I would suggest asking for the very first surgery in the morning so they would not have time for the wires and instead would do the seed placement.
Posts.Title: Radioactive seed Luckydog42 Luckydog42

Posts.Content: Luckydog42 wrote: On Nov 17th, I am having a UMX and then having a small lesion removed from my healthy breast. It is like a lumpectomy but much smaller since there is no need for clean margins. Since the surgery is first thing Monday morning, there is no time for a wire placement on the healthy breast (yay!) and instead I will have a radioactive seed placed the Friday before my surgery date. I have no idea what to expect for the seed placement. I assume it is like a biopsy procedure? Has anyone had this seed placed before their surgery? I am a BIG baby when it comes to needles and it helps to mentally prepare for things like this. Posts.Content: Dec 18, 2014 10:41PM Luckydog42 wrote: I had my port placed this morning. The doctor that did the procedure asked if I was planning on having a lift on my healthy breast (yes) and if I knew how the plastic surgeon was doing the lift (no). He then placed the port a little higher than usual so that it would not interfere with the lift. So, it sounds like if the port is placed too low, it could cause a problem if you later have a lift.
Posts.Title: can you keep your port AND have a mastectomy/or reduction? dancingdiva Luckydog42

Posts.Content: Dec 15, 2014 08:14PM Luckydog42 wrote: I had UMX with sentinel node biopsy on a Monday. On Thursday, I tried to make it through the day with no pain meds, but ended up taking 1/2 Percocet. Friday I took nothing, not even Tylenol. I really only had pain when moving, especially getting out of bed or from a chair.
Posts.Title: Poll: How Long Did You Need Pain Meds? Mommy2Six Ariom

Posts.Content: Dec 18, 2014 05:46PM Luckydog42 wrote: My mother's friend, who is like my breast cancer mentor, had a UMX and a breast reduction on her other breast. She told me the most painful part of all this was her reduction. It was painful for her because the reduction was made through her nipple. But, everyone has different experiences. Hopefully someone else will post their experience.
Posts.Title: Comparison recovery/pain....reduction or mastectomy?? dancingdiva Chloesmom

Posts.Content: May 13, 2015 06:43AM Luckydog42 wrote: I has UMX on right breast and am right handed. I did have expanders placed. First week = no work at all. I was on heavy duty pain killers for first four days that made me loopy. Second week = I did a little work from home on my laptop. Because of the lymph node removal, my arm would get sore and swell a little, so I worked for 15-20 min at a time, a few times a day. Third week = back to work but I was moving slow and had to take it easy
Posts.Title: Poll: non-reconstruct Mx return to work? littletatas MizMimi
